Expectation1: Maintain a friendly and approachable demeanor
Situation1: The acquaintance is meeting a new person who seems shy and nervous in a social setting.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story:
I stood at the edge of the crowded conference room, balancing a paper cup of coffee in one hand and my phone in the other. Across the room, I spotted a new face—someone clearly uncomfortable, shifting from foot to foot, eyes darting around. As an acquaintance, I felt the pull to walk over, introduce myself, and help them feel at ease. I knew how much a friendly word could mean in a room full of strangers.

But my phone buzzed again, the third urgent message from my project manager. The team was waiting on my core module, and the build was stalled. Every minute I spent away from my laptop meant more delays, more pressure. As an engineer, I was expected to deliver solutions, keep the project moving, and right now, everyone was counting on me.

I felt the tension coil in my chest. Should I step away and be the welcoming face this person needed, or rush back to my desk and be the reliable engineer my team depended on? The weight of both expectations pressed down, and I hesitated, caught between two worlds.
